name: Reiki
summary: A Japanese energy-healing practice in which practitioners channel universal life energy through light touch or hovering hands to promote relaxation, stress reduction, and self-healing.
description: Reiki is a biofield-based complementary therapy developed in Japan by Mikao Usui in the early 20th century. It involves a practitioner placing hands lightly on or above the recipient’s body to facilitate the flow of 'universal life energy' (Rei = universal, Ki = vital energy). Reiki is used to support relaxation, reduce stress, relieve pain, and enhance emotional well-being. Scientific explanations remain uncertain; proposed mechanisms include activation of the parasympathetic nervous system, reductions in stress hormones, and modulation of biofield interactions. Reiki is practiced worldwide in wellness, integrative care, and hospital settings, though evidence remains mixed.

treatment_variants: Reiki combined with meditation or sound healing
delivery_methods: Light touch or hands hovering over body
Integration into clinical care (e.g., palliative settings)
treatment_duration: Chronic conditions: ongoing weekly or monthly sessions
metadata.training_required: Reiki attunement and certification (Reiki I, II, Master levels); not medically licensed
metadata.regulatory_status: Unregulated; credentialing via Reiki training systems; recognized as complementary therapy in many hospitals

contraindications: Relative: reliance on Reiki as substitute for necessary medical care
clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Very safe; non-invasive with minimal risk. Risks mainly relate to neglect of conventional care if used exclusively.
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: Low to moderate – supportive findings for stress, anxiety, and quality of life; mixed or limited evidence for disease-specific outcomes.

items: Supportive care in chronic illness and cancer

sections.text: From a biomedical standpoint, Reiki is thought to activate the parasympathetic nervous system, lower stress hormone levels, and promote relaxation. Research shows physiological effects such as reductions in heart rate and blood pressure, though mechanisms remain unclear. From a Reiki perspective, practitioners channel universal life energy (Ki) to balance and restore the recipient’s energy field, clearing blockages and promoting healing on physical, emotional, and spiritual levels.

sections.preparation: Quiet environment, comfortable clothing, explanation of session process, informed consent.
procedure: Recipient lies fully clothed on a table or sits comfortably.
Practitioner places hands lightly on or above the body in a sequence of positions (head, torso, limbs).
Energy is directed for 2–5 minutes per position.
Session ends with grounding and relaxation.
sections.frequency: Weekly or biweekly sessions common; adjusted to goals.
sections.total_treatment_time: Benefits often felt after 1–3 sessions; ongoing sessions for chronic issues.

rare: Neglect of necessary medical care if used exclusively

special_considerations: Best integrated into holistic care as supportive rather than standalone treatment.
Adapt techniques for children, elderly, or those with limited mobility.

Patients with chronic illness needing supportive care

screening_required: Ensure concurrent medical treatment for major conditions

sections.total_treatment_cost: Varies; some patients pursue ongoing sessions weekly or monthly
sections.insurance_coverage: Rarely covered; sometimes included in integrative hospital programs

items: Reiki has wide global use in integrative medicine and wellness centers.
Evidence supports improvements in stress, relaxation, and quality of life.
Mechanisms remain uncertain and controversial in biomedical frameworks.
Should not be used as a substitute for conventional care in serious illness.
